unnormalised: Someone asked about the population distribution in India, and it's quite interesting. According to the 2011 census (which is still our most reliable nationwide data), India's population was around 1.21 billion. Experts estimate it to be around 1.4 billion in 2023. The next official census was supposed to happen in 2021, but it's been delayed, so we are still using older data.
normalised: Someone asked about the population distribution in India, and it's quite interesting. According to the two thousand eleven census, which is still our most reliable nationwide data, India's population was around one point two one billion. Experts estimate it to be around one point four billion in two thousand twenty three. The next official census was supposed to happen in two thousand twenty one, but it's been delayed, so we are still using older data.

unnormalised: Now, when we consider the distribution, Uttar Pradesh (UP) is the most populous state, boasting a population close to 200 million (as per 2011 census). On the other hand, Sikkim has a very small population, around 600,000. The density also varies greatly, from 11,320 persons per sq km in Delhi to just 13 persons per sq km in Arunachal Pradesh. This disparity affects everything from resource allocation to political representation.

unnormalised: Age distribution also plays a crucial role. In 2011, the median age was around 24 years. By 2023, estimates put it closer to 28 years. As the population ages, India needs to focus on policies that support an aging workforce and healthcare needs. The child sex ratio, which was 919 females per 1000 males in the 0-6 age group in 2011, is also a crucial indicator of social development.

unnormalised: Understanding these numbers is vital for planning and policy making. We look forward to seeing more detailed insights when the 2021 census data becomes available.
